articles.headline: Meet the People Trying to Put a Friendlier Face on Annuities
articles.snippet: There is a boomlet in kinder, gentler annuity providers, and they want you to devote some of your savings to guaranteeing more retirement income for yourself.
articles.abstract: There is a boomlet in kinder, gentler annuity providers, and they want you to devote some of your savings to guaranteeing more retirement income for yourself.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saving for retirement requires a strange sort of oddsmaking.

articles.headline: JD.com Chief Richard Liu Will Not Be Charged With Sexual Assault
articles.snippet: Prosecutors in Minnesota said they did not find enough evidence to pursue a case against the Chinese billionaire, who was accused of rape this year by a University of Minnesota student.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors in Minnesota said they did not find enough evidence to pursue a case against the Chinese billionaire, who was accused of rape this year by a University of Minnesota student.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard Liu, the Chinese billionaire accused of rape nearly four months ago by a young Chinese student at the University of Minnesota, will not be charged with sexual assault, prosecutors in Minneapolis said on Friday.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Raymond Zhong

articles.headline: Supreme Court Won’t Revive Trump Policy Limiting Asylum
articles.snippet: Lower courts said the policy, which barred asylum applications from people who had entered the country unlawfully, conflicted with federal law.
articles.abstract: Lower courts said the policy, which barred asylum applications from people who had entered the country unlawfully, conflicted with federal law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court refused on Friday to allow the Trump administration to immediately enforce its new policy of denying asylum to migrants who illegally cross the Mexican border.

articles.headline: As Markets Tumble, Tech Stocks Hit a Rare and Ominous Milestone
articles.snippet: Technology companies are dragging stocks into an ominous territory that the market hasn’t seen in nearly a decade: a severe decline known as a bear market.
articles.abstract: Technology companies are dragging stocks into an ominous territory that the market hasn’t seen in nearly a decade: a severe decline known as a bear market.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to the stock market, America’s technology giants have become a harbinger of more pain to come.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Matt Phillips

articles.headline: Trump Policy Gyrations Threaten Fragile Republican Coalition
articles.snippet: With his willingness to force a government shutdown and his sudden decision to withdraw troops from Syria, the president is straining links to mainstream G.O.P. governance.
articles.abstract: With his willingness to force a government shutdown and his sudden decision to withdraw troops from Syria, the president is straining links to mainstream G.O.P. governance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s near-simultaneous decisions this week to force a government shutdown over his demand to fund a border wall and withdraw American troops from Syria and Afghanistan have imperiled the fragile Republican coalition, exacerbating the party’s fears about what may become of his presidency — and its own electoral prospects in 2020.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Why the F.T.C. Is Taking a New Look at Facebook Privacy
articles.snippet: In 2011, Facebook agreed to settle charges that it had deceived consumers on privacy. But new problems have resurfaced old concerns.
articles.abstract: In 2011, Facebook agreed to settle charges that it had deceived consumers on privacy. But new problems have resurfaced old concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a yearlong string of news reports that have called Facebook’s data-sharing practices into question, federal regulators are taking a hard look at how the social media company handles the personal information of its users.

articles.headline: In Gupta Brothers’ Rise and Fall, the Tale of a Sullied A.N.C.
articles.snippet: An Indian family rose to the heights of power and fortune in South Africa with the help of eager officials in the legendary party of Nelson Mandela.
articles.abstract: An Indian family rose to the heights of power and fortune in South Africa with the help of eager officials in the legendary party of Nelson Mandela.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAHARANPUR, India — India’s most influential guru joined thousands of believers four years ago as the temple’s first stone was set in the ground.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Selam Gebrekidan

articles.headline: Government Shutdown to Continue for Days as Senate Adjourns Until Thursday
articles.snippet: Senate Democrats said they would never accede to President Trump’s demand for $5 billion for a border wall, and the White House offered no early indication that the president would accept less.
articles.abstract: Senate Democrats said they would never accede to President Trump’s demand for $5 billion for a border wall, and the White House offered no early indication that the president would accept less.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the White House and Democrats remained locked in a standoff over funding for President Trump’s border wall, Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, sent his colleagues home for the Christmas holiday on Saturday, virtually ensuring that the government will remain partially shuttered for at least several more days.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: Corruption in South Africa: A Guide to Our Recent Reporting
articles.snippet: South Africa’s corruption scandals have upended the country’s view of their governing party, the African National Congress, threatening decades of power.
articles.abstract: South Africa’s corruption scandals have upended the country’s view of their governing party, the African National Congress, threatening decades of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: First they heard about the spies. Then they heard about the secret brothels and the private planes. And the whole time, they were hearing about the assassins.

articles.headline: For Trump, ‘a War Every Day,’ Waged Increasingly Alone
articles.snippet: At the midpoint of his term, the president has grown more sure of his own judgment and more isolated from anyone else’s than at any point since he took office.
articles.abstract: At the midpoint of his term, the president has grown more sure of his own judgment and more isolated from anyone else’s than at any point since he took office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump grows frustrated with advisers during meetings, which is not an uncommon occurrence, he sits back in his chair, crosses his arms and scowls. Often he erupts. “Freaking idiots!” he calls his aides. Except he uses a more pungent word than “freaking.”
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: How to Keep Baby Jesus in the Manger? Bolts, Cameras and Tethers
articles.snippet: As thefts at nativity scenes rise, communities are turning to elaborate security measures. “People aren’t living the gospel,” one pastor said of the heists.
articles.abstract: As thefts at nativity scenes rise, communities are turning to elaborate security measures. “People aren’t living the gospel,” one pastor said of the heists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BETHLEHEM, Pa. — Away in a manger on Bethlehem’s public square, a woman approached a statue of the baby Jesus one dark, December night. Then she stole it.

articles.headline: Women’s March Roiled by Accusations of Anti-Semitism
articles.snippet: As the second anniversary of the Women’s March approaches, charges of anti-Semitism are overshadowing the movement and plans for more marches.
articles.abstract: As the second anniversary of the Women’s March approaches, charges of anti-Semitism are overshadowing the movement and plans for more marches.
articles.lead_paragraph: Within days of Donald J. Trump’s election, a diverse group of women united by their concern about the incoming administration gathered at a restaurant in New York to plan a protest march in Washington. They had seen the idea floating on Facebook and wanted to turn it into a reality.

articles.headline: A Shutdown for Weeks? Washington Merely Shrugs
articles.snippet: With a resolution further out of grip, a sense of resignation settled over lawmakers, in a sharp contrast to the frenzied political warfare of previous shutdowns.
articles.abstract: With a resolution further out of grip, a sense of resignation settled over lawmakers, in a sharp contrast to the frenzied political warfare of previous shutdowns.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a partial shutdown of the federal government entered its second day on Sunday and the prospect of a quick resolution to a dispute over President Trump’s border wall slipped further out of grip, a normally fevered Washington found itself mustering little more than a collective shrug.

articles.headline: Trump, Angry Over Mattis’s Rebuke, Removes Him 2 Months Early
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump, in a Twitter post, said that Patrick M. Shanahan, Mr. Mattis’s deputy, would serve as the acting defense secretary.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump, in a Twitter post, said that Patrick M. Shanahan, Mr. Mattis’s deputy, would serve as the acting defense secretary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Less than two hours after Defense Secretary Jim Mattis went to the White House on Thursday to hand a resignation letter to President Trump, the president stood in the Oval Office and dictated a glowing tweet announcing that Mr. Mattis was retiring “with distinction” at the end of February.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: John Roberts, Leader of Supreme Court’s Conservative Majority, Fights Perception That It Is Partisan
articles.snippet: “We don’t work as Democrats or Republicans,” he has said, a theme he has returned to while trying to strike a delicate balance as the chief justice.
articles.abstract: “We don’t work as Democrats or Republicans,” he has said, a theme he has returned to while trying to strike a delicate balance as the chief justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his first 13 years on the Supreme Court, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s main challenge was trying to assemble five votes to move the court to the right, though there were only four reliably conservative justices.

articles.headline: Stock Market Rout Has Trump Fixated on Fed Chair Powell
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump increasingly blames the Fed for the downtrend in stock prices. Some investors say the president himself is the bigger problem.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump increasingly blames the Fed for the downtrend in stock prices. Some investors say the president himself is the bigger problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has unabashedly hitched his political fortunes to a rising stock market. Now, with stock prices in retreat, he has become increasingly fixated on the idea that one man is to blame for the recent rout: Jerome H. Powell, chairman of the Federal Reserve.

articles.headline: In Nicaragua, Ortega Was on the Ropes. Now, He Has Protesters on the Run.
articles.snippet: When huge protests demanded that he leave office, President Daniel Ortega’s days seemed numbered. But his repressive response has sent thousands into hiding and tightened his hold on power.
articles.abstract: When huge protests demanded that he leave office, President Daniel Ortega’s days seemed numbered. But his repressive response has sent thousands into hiding and tightened his hold on power.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAGUA, Nicaragua — A life on the run was not one any of these Nicaraguans ever intended.
